chapters.display_text:
It is a grey day in Fukashima prefecture, Japan. Driving through the deserted villages of Okuma and Futaba, you see abandoned houses and other small buildings slowly being taken over by vegetation. Eventually you reach the site of the Fukashima II Nuclear Power Plant. There is a bustle of activity as the cleanup operation continues.
It’s possible to get from the car park to the main building without protective clothing, but you still see people wearing face masks.
In the briefing room a TEPCO engineer walks over to greet you and hands you a hard hat.
He suggests an introduction in unit 5 to get your bearings before getting to work investigating the radiother reactors.
There is a corridor north that leads to the changing rooms and reactor unit 5.
There is a corridor south that leads to the robot control room.

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text:
The changing rooms are very bright and sterile. A radiation shielding jumpsuit, gloves, breathing mask, and goggles on a bench near the entrance.
There is a door to the north leading to reactor unit 5.
There is a door to the south leading back to the briefing room.

actions.walk north: The engineer stops you and politely suggests you put on protective clothing.
actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text:
The engineer helps you put the jumpsuit and gloves on, taping up the gap between the sleeves and gloves. You put on the face mask which makes it harder to breath. The goggles under the hard hat make things more uncomfortable.
You are ready to head north to reactor unit 5

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text:
You head to a long corridor and make you way to reactor 5 with the engineer.
Entering the reactor building, there is a large red hatch which is used to access the primary containment vessel.
The engineer advises to keep an eye on your dosimeter which measures the surrounding radiation levels.
Movement is uncomfortable and hot as you carefully navigate through a confusing jumble of walkways, pipes and machinery in the PCV.
You end up under the reactor core.
There is a walkway heading back to the changing rooms.

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text:
You are currently standing directly below reactor 5's core in an area known as the pedestal.
There is not enough space to stand up straight and you stoop low to avoid hitting your head against control rods protruding out of the reactor core.
The engineer explains that it is this same area in reactors 2 and 3 where radioactive fuel is thought to have melted through the reactor core.
There is walkway south which leads back to the changing rooms

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text:
You and the engineer navigate the walkways and corridor back to the changing rooms.
The changing rooms are a relief after the cramp conditions in the reactor.
There is a door to the north leading to reactor unit 5.
There is a door to the south leading back to the briefing room.

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text: The engineer politely suggests that you remove your protective clothing

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text:
You are back in the breifing room. 
There is a corridor north that leads to the changing rooms and reactor unit 5.
There is a corridor south that leads to the robot control room.

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text:
You enter a busy control room. There is a desk with two screens. Beneath each of these screens sits a control panel and joystick. The engineer gestures for you to take a seat at the desk and operate one of the controls.
One screen is labelled 'Reactor 2: Scorpion'.
The other screen is labelled 'Reactor 3: Little Sunfish'
The door to the north leads back to the breifing room

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text: The screen springs to life and displays a feed from the 'Scorpion' robot. So-called because it can lift up its camera-mounted tail to achieve better viewing angles, is also designed to crawl over rubble inside the damaged reactor.

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text: The screen springs to life and displays a feed from the 'Little Sunfish' aquatic robot. The size of a loaf of bread, the little sunfish is equipped for its tough mission with lights, manoeuvres with tail propellers and can collect data with two cameras and a dosimeter to measure radiation.

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text:
The scorpion starts moving down the ramp of service hatch X-6 of reactor 2. The video from the little robot's camera shows a hazy image of rubble and debris, dimly lit by robot's lights.
The video starts to degrade, probably due to the high amounts of radiation in the reactor building.
The controls become non-responsive and the video feed is lost.

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text:
The little sunfish starts swimming towards service hatch X-53 of reactor 3. The video from the robot's camera shows a hazy image of the flooded reactor building.
Rubble lies all over the floor and fine particles float in front of the camera
You pilot the robot into the Pedastal under the reactor core. The dosimeter readings from the robot spikes over 500 sieverts.
Pointing the robot down you see what looks like lava rocks. You've found what was once the base of the reactor containment vessel, mixed with melted nuclear fuel.
 Job Done!

actions.default: you don’t have time for that

chapters.display_text: Congratulations. For more information on the Fukashima robots have a look at http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-40696303
